"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec2fe6368722ee31d0000#post_537ec2fe6368722ee31d0000
okay, you seriously need to stop thinking with your feelings.


1. No laws governing marriage will be passed
2. marriage will still exist as a social institution, simply two people living together in a working partnership
3. As long as nothing already illegal is going on (abuse, etc) the government will not step in

Therefore, the issue of gay marriage doesn't exist.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec3f46368722c275e0000#post_537ec3f46368722c275e0000
Actually _you_ are the one thinking with feelings; you are basing these "laws" on your own hate/dislike for marriage equality, basically "I don't like them gays so I'm gonna make it so they are treated differently because my personal preference to sexual orientation should interfere with someone's private life." 

I hate smoking, like _really_ hate it. It is a filthy disgusting habit and I with people would stop smoking because I know how bad it can be.

But I would never take away someone's freedom to smoke because it is their life and their body.

Personal preference has no place in lawmaking. 

As an edit, marriage I believe should exist and therefore be governed somehow as the official union between people. To not have any kind of marriage structure pretty much says that marriage which many people hold sacred is basically just pretend.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec4be6368725ddd000000#post_537ec4be6368725ddd000000
Cause running a successful government has tons of theories on how to make the perfect utopia, but in practice as far as we know there is no such thing as a perfect utopia(tm) sort of governing.  Having marriage as a social contract sounds good in practice, but in reality that would cause a shit ton of problems business and taxes wise as partners to gain tax breaks for being in a marriage which would cause groups to try to only recognize the social contracts of heterosexual marriages and you're back to square one.  Also before you say, "well what if there's no tax breaks for married individuals?" that would totally fuck the country's population growth and would cause people to stop wanting to have enough children to continue to keep the population stable (cough) Like how the usa just fucked themselves cause birth rates are now at 1.8 kids per couple, it's been going down at a alarming rate, and how in the long run that's going to fuck us hard in the long run (cough)

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec6256368726108400000#post_537ec6256368726108400000
people will have kids regardless.
Tax breaks for kids have nothing to do with marriage actually, and is not at all applicable to gays outside of adoption. And gays who adopt kids will get some tax break as well.

And no tax breaks for marriage (since it is already an economic partnership)kind of defeats your first point if I understand you correctly.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec6256368726108400000#post_537ec6256368726108400000
I don't think married couples should get any kinds of benefits, it's not fair. Just because someone found someone that they love and someone else did not they now must be treated differently. What's more, these benefits may encourage marriage between people who don't even love each other, they are just doing ti for the money or other benefits. I think marriage would be about love and the desire to be with that person, nothing else.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec6256368726108400000#post_537ec6256368726108400000
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec5b2636872608e430000#post_537ec5b2636872608e430000
Idealistically I side with Whatevs on the idea that it is absolutely no business of the government's who I marry so long as they are a consenting adult and that all the benefits (hospital visitation, adoption, custody, next of kin, insurance, ect.) should more properly be hashed out through contract law followed up by whatever ceremony the individuals involved feel appropriate, however practically I have to side with uc9.

Completely dismantling the machinery of government, no matter how obnoxious or unwanted it is will result in more damage than simply changing and expanding the law.

TL;DR: For all intents and purposes the best way forward is to make gay marriage legal on a national level as taking apart the existing legal framework would be too destructive.
topics.author: 4f41ee04945b701c41002af7
